Article.Abstract: NY-ESO-1, a commonly expressed tumor antigen of the cancer-testis family, is expressed by a wide range of tumors but not found in normal adult somatic tissue, making it an ideal cancer vaccine candidate. Peptides derived from NY-ESO-1 have shown preclinical and clinical trial promise; however, biochemical features of these peptides have complicated their formulation and led to heterogeneous immune responses. We have taken a rational approach to engineer an HLA A2-restricted NY-ESO-1-derived T cell epitope with improved formulation and immunogenicity to the wild type peptide. To accomplish this, we have solved the x-ray crystallographic structures of HLA A2 complexed to NY-ESO (157-165) and two analogues of this peptide in which the C-terminal cysteine residue has been substituted to alanine or serine. Substitution of cysteine by serine maintained peptide conformation yet reduced complex stability, resulting in poor cytotoxic T lymphocyte recognition. Conversely, substitution with alanine maintained complex stability and cytotoxic T lymphocyte recognition. Based on the structures of the three HLA A2 complexes, we incorporated 2-aminoisobutyric acid, an isostereomer of cysteine, into the epitope. This analogue is impervious to oxidative damage, cysteinylation, and dimerization of the peptide epitope upon formulation that is characteristic of the wild type peptide. Therefore, this approach has yielded a potential therapeutic molecule that satiates the hydrophobic F pocket of HLA A2 and exhibited superior immunogenicity relative to the wild type peptide.
Article.ArticleTitle: Functional and structural characteristics of NY-ESO-1-related HLA A2-restricted epitopes and the design of a novel immunogenic analogue.
Article.Affiliations: Protein Crystallography Unit and Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, School of Biomedical Sciences, Monash University, Clayton, Victoria 3800, Australia.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Antigens, Neoplasm;CTAG1B protein, human;Cancer Vaccines;Epitopes;HLA-A2 Antigen;Membrane Proteins
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Adult; Antigens, Neoplasm(chemistry; immunology); Cancer Vaccines; Drug Design; Epitopes(chemistry); HLA-A2 Antigen(chemistry; immunology); Humans; Male; Membrane Proteins(chemistry; immunology); Models, Molecular; Protein Conformation

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Epitope-specific CTL lines were derived from delayed type hypersensitivity biopsy after HLA- A2+ melanoma patients bearing NY-ESO-positive tumors were vaccinated with epitope during a clinical trial. NY-ESO-1 positive melanoma patients were vaccinated with epitope during a clinical trial. From a delayed type hypersensitivity biopsy, CTL lines were generated by in vitro expansion in the presence of wild type peptide pulsed APCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Two independent CTL lines, derived from NY-ESO-1 positive cancer patients, recognized epitope-pulsed target cells (TAP deficient human line T2) in a dose dependent fashion. The CTL also recognized the analog peptides with residue Cys9 substituted with Ala, Val, Ser or the non-natural amino acid 2-aminobutyric acid. The order of reactivity was C9Abu > C9A > C9V > wild type > C9S, which did not correlate directly with binding or stability of the complexes.

MhcBinding.LocationOfData: Figures 1, 2 Tables II, III and PDB 1S9W

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Assembly of peptide-MHC complexes is shown to be dose-dependent in the peptide concentration range tested (0.5 to 10 μM).

Epitope.EpitopeName: C9S analog of cancer/testis antigen NY-ESO-1 peptide 157-165

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide is an analog of cancer/testis antigen NY-ESO-1 peptide 157-165, where cysteine at position 9 is substituted by serine.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The complex between this analog and MHC molecules is shown to be 10ºC less stable than the equivalent complex with wild type peptide.
Assembly of peptide-MHC complexes is shown to be slightly worse with this analog epitope than with the wild type peptide.

ThreeDimensionalStructureOfComplex.Comments: The structure of the C9S [PDB: 1S9Y] and C9A [PDB: 1S9X] peptide analogues bound to HLA-A2 are extremely similar to the wild type NY-ESO-(157-165)-HLA-A2 complex [PDB: 1S9W]. Additional hydrogen bond between S9 of the peptide analogue and HLA leads to a decrease in the complex stability compared with stability of the wild-type peptide-HLA complex.

Epitope.EpitopeName: C9A analog of cancer/testis antigen NY-ESO-1 peptide 157-165

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide is an analog of cancer/testis antigen NY-ESO-1 peptide 157-165, where cysteine at position 9 is susbtituted by alanine.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The complex between this analog epitope and MHC molecules is shown to be as stable as the complex with the wild type peptide.

ThreeDimensionalStructureOfComplex.Comments: The structure of the C9S [PDB: 1S9Y] and C9A [PDB: 1S9X] peptide analogues bound to HLA- A2 are extremely similar to the wild type NY-ESO-(157-165)-HLA-A2 complex [PDB: 1S9W]. C9A analogue is equivalent to the wild-type peptide in cross-sensitizing target cells for recognition.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Assembly of epitope-MHC complexes is shown to be similarly effective with this analog as with the wild type peptide.

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide is an analog of cancer/testis antigen NY-ESO-1 peptide 157-165, where cysteine at position 9 is susbtituted by valine.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Assembly of epitope-MHC complexes is shown to be more effective with this analog than with the wild type peptide.
The complex between this analog and MHC molecules is shown to be 4.5ºC more stable than the complex with the wild type peptide.

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide is an analog of cancer/testis antigen NY-ESO-1 peptide 157-165 (SLLMWITQC), where cysteine at position 9 is substituted by its isosteric non-natural amino acid 2-aminoisobutyric acid (Abu), such that the thiol group of cysteine is replaced by a methyl group.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The complex between the analog epitope and the MHC molecule is shown to be 1.5°C more stable than the complex with the wild type peptide.
Assembly of peptide-MHC complexes is shown to be slightly less effective with this analog than with the wild type peptide.
